entry.title: Jury resumes death penalty deliberations for Colorado theater shooter James Holmes
entry.summary: Jurors must decide whether there are any reasons, such as Holmes' mental illness and his trouble-free youth, that mean he should be sentenced to life in prison without parole instead of to death.

entry.title: Deliberations resume in Colorado theater shooting trial
entry.summary: If jurors unanimously agree that such factors outweigh the heinousness of the July 2012 attack that killed 12 people and injured 70 others, Holmes would be sentenced to a life term.

entry.title: Colorado shooting defendant James Holmes called ?psychotic? by his attorney
entry.summary:
Daniel King said Holmes had been mentally ill even before the 2012 attack on the movie theater in Aurora, Colo., and urged the jurors to look beyond how the gunman planned his attack.

The prosecution had earlier argued that the deliberate nature of the planning and execution of the attack showed that Holmes was not mentally ill.

In his presentation, Brauchler emphasized how Holmes deliberately planned the attack to compensate for failures in his graduate school studies and in his romantic life.

entry.title: Jimmy Fallon Mangles Katie Holmes?s Face
'Tonight': Say Anything with Katie Holmes
Colorado theater shooter deserves to die, prosecutors say
entry.summary: The monthlong penalty phase of the trial of Holmes, who could be sentenced to death for killing 12 people in a Colorado movie theater, began Wednesday morning with the judge giving instructions to the jury.

entry.title: The Latest: Colorado shooting jurors to review Holmes video
entry.summary:
The jurors were given permission to view a recording of Holmes after the shooting in which he asks police officers if any children were hurt.

Lawyers for Colorado theater shooter James Holmes did not make any arguments disputing that the crime makes him eligible for the death penalty.

The penalty phase of the trial starts Wednesday with prosecutors telling jurors why Holmes should be eligible for execution.

entry.title: Ian McKellen's not slowing down, taking 'Mr. Holmes' on a thoughtful journey
entry.summary:
And in "Mr. Holmes," which opens this weekend, McKellen inhabits both a reflective 93-year-old Sherlock Holmes and his younger self.

"Kept going" is also evident in "Holmes," in which McKellen finds himself in nearly every scene, in a part as physically nuanced and demanding as any senior-citizen role around.

Still, as the nonagenarian Sherlock Holmes might remind, powers don't remain sharp forever, and a life is vital until it's not.

entry.title: Colorado theater shooter James Holmes guilty of murder
entry.summary:
They called two psychiatrists, including a nationally known schizophrenia expert, who concluded Holmes was psychotic and legally insane.

Jurors watched nearly 22 hours of videotaped interviews showing Holmes talking in a flat, mechanical tone about his desire to kill strangers to increase his self-worth.

Prosecutors showed jurors Holmes' spiral notebook, where he scribbled a self-diagnosis of his "broken mind" and described his "obsession to kill" since childhood.

entry.title: Holmes will join many other mentally ill inmates in prison
Holmes will join many other mentally ill inmates in prison
entry.summary: Despite having convicted Holmes in the killings, jurors must still determine whether to put Holmes on death row for opening fire in the crowded movie theater.

entry.title: Ian McKellen delivers in 'Mr. Holmes'
Movie review: 'Mr Holmes' makes Sherlock seem real
entry.summary: In "Mr. Holmes," Ian McKellen and director Bill Condon reunite for another story about an aging man confronting his mortality.

entry.title: Despite quick conviction, trial of Colorado theater shooter James Holmes is far from over
entry.summary:
- Families of the 12 people James Holmes killed and the scores he injured in a packed movie theater were relieved that jurors only needed 12 hours to reject the idea that he was legally insane when he opened fire.

Now the trial enters a new phase as the jury decides whether Holmes should die for his crimes.

Starting next week, jurors will hear testimony about Holmes' mental illness and his childhood.

Prosecutors may counter with even more heartbreaking accounts from victims, ranging from those Holmes maimed to the father of his youngest victim, a 6-year-old girl who died in the 2012 attack.

There was a muted, heartbroken sense of relief Thursday afternoon following Holmes' conviction on 165 counts of murder, attempted murder and other charges.

entry.title: The Latest: Theater shooting survivor says she has closure
entry.summary: Colorado theater shooting survivor Jansen Young says she finally has closure with the guilty verdict against shooter James Holmes.

entry.title: The Latest: Theater shooting survivor says she has closure
entry.summary: Colorado theater shooter James Holmes is showing no visible reaction as the judge reads the jury's verdict on all 165 counts against him.

entry.title: Timeline of events leading to guilty verdicts in Colorado theater shooting case
entry.summary:
Dec. 13, 1987 - Holmes is born in San Diego County, California, to Robert and Arlene Holmes.

2011 - Holmes enrolls in the Ph.D. neuroscience program at the University of Colorado's Anschutz Medical Campus in the Denver suburb of Aurora.

February 2012 - Holmes and Gargi Datta break off their relationship.

July 20, 2012 - Holmes slips through a back door of the Century 16 theater in Aurora, where about 420 people are watching a midnight showing of a Batman movie, "The Dark Knight Rises," and opens fire.

entry.title: Colorado theatre shooter James Holmes guilty of murder
entry.summary: Centennial, Colorado: A US jury has found Colorado theatre shooter James Holmes guilty of murder for the attack that left 12 dead and dozens wounded.

entry.title: Batman shooter trial: James Holmes verdict - live
entry.summary: If Holmes is convicted of first degree murder, a decision to spare his life in the penalty phase would result in a mandatory life sentence without the possibility of parole.

entry.title: Batman shooter trial: James Holmes verdict - live
entry.summary: If the jury agrees that Holmes was insane, he would avoid execution and likely spend the rest of his life committed to the state's mental hospital in Pueblo, 100 miles (160 km) south of Denver.

entry.title: Jurors reach verdict in trial of Colorado movie gunman
entry.summary:
The jury in the Colorado movie massacre trial reached a verdict on Thursday, the second day of deliberations in the case of 27-year-old gunman James Holmes, who has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity, a court spokesman said.

Holmes did not testify in his own defense, but jurors watched video of some 23 hours of interviews conducted with him by one of the court-appointed psychiatrists.

entry.title: Verdict reached against Colorado theater gunman James Holmes
entry.summary: Prosecutors honed in on Holmes' elaborate planning of the massacre.

entry.title: James Holmes' trial: A look at key aspects as closings begin
entry.summary:
Holmes surrendered to police outside the theater.

They also examined scores of pieces of evidence, including Holmes' guns and ammunition.

entry.title: Lawyers in theater shooting trial make final appeals to jury
entry.summary: Jurors in the Colorado theater shooting case soon will retreat into the largest jury room in the courthouse to determine whether Holmes was legally insane at the time of the killing spree.

entry.title: Lawyers in theater shooting trial make final appeals to jury
entry.summary: King pleaded with jurors to believe that Holmes' mental illness was the sole cause of the attack.

entry.title: After all is said in theater attack trial, was Holmes sane?
entry.summary: A copy of Colorado's insanity statute will guide them in the jury room as they consider Holmes' mental state that night, analyzing his medical records, family history, police reports and journal.

entry.title: After all is said in theater attack trial, was Holmes sane?
entry.summary:
The only question they must answer is whether Holmes met Colorado's threshold for an insanity verdict, by suffering from mental illness so severe that it rendered him unable to tell right from wrong at the time of the shootings.

The hideous details of the attack, the heartbreaking survival stories, the signs of mental illness that Holmes showed well before the events of July 20, 2012 - they shouldn't matter.

If they agree Holmes is insane, he would be committed indefinitely to a state mental hospital.
